title: Why Running Slower Might Make You Faster
excerpt: New research shows 80% of runners train too hard on easy days. Elite coaches now recommend slowing down your recovery runs to build aerobic capacity without burnout. One simple change could unlock your next PR.
body:
New research from the Journal of Applied Physiology shows that 80% of recreational runners train too hard on their easy days, leading to chronic fatigue and plateaued performance.

Elite coaches like Renato Canova and Jack Daniels have long advocated for the 80/20 rule: 80% of your running should be at an easy, conversational pace, with only 20% at moderate to high intensity.

The science is clear: easy runs build mitochondrial density, improve fat oxidation, and allow your body to recover while still maintaining fitness. Running too hard every day leads to accumulated stress without adequate recovery.

Try this: For the next two weeks, slow down your easy runs by 30-60 seconds per mile. You might feel like you're jogging at first, but your body will thank you with faster race times later.

Key takeaway: The path to running faster often starts with running slower.
